description:
Urocitellus parryii, commonly known as the Arctic ground squirrel, is a species of ground squirrel found in the Arctic regions of North America. It is a member of the genus Urocitellus, which includes various species of ground squirrels.

The Arctic ground squirrel is a medium-sized rodent, typically measuring between 25 to 40 centimeters in length, including its bushy tail. It has a distinctive reddish-brown or gray-brown fur coat that helps it camouflage in its natural habitat, which includes tundra, alpine, and sub-Arctic environments.

These ground squirrels are known for their remarkable ability to hibernate during the harsh winter months, entering a state of deep torpor to conserve energy and survive the extreme cold. They are adept at building extensive underground burrow systems, which they use for nesting, storage of food, and hibernation.

Arctic ground squirrels are important prey species for various predators, such as arctic foxes, wolverines, and birds of prey. They play a crucial role in the Arctic ecosystem, contributing to the food web and serving as ecosystem engineers through their burrowing activities.

Conservation efforts for the Arctic ground squirrel focus on maintaining the integrity of its natural habitats, which are increasingly threatened by climate change and human activities in the Arctic region.
